form-instructions.married: To estimate your benefits, we will need the following information from your and your partner's {{year}} tax returns.
form-instructions.single: To estimate your benefits, we will need the following information from your {{year}} tax return
form-instructions.note: If any total amounts are negative or zero, enter '0'.

info.claimed-income: Income claimed by you (line 11700 and line 12500 of your tax return).
info.claimed-repayment: Repayment claimed by you (line 21300 and line 23200 of your tax return).
info.partner-claimed-income: Income claimed by your partner (line 11700 and line 12500 of their tax return).
info.partner-claimed-repayment: Repayment claimed by your partner (line 21300 and line 23200 of their tax return).
info.partner-net-income: Line 23600 on your partner's tax return.

items: Taxable scholarships, fellowships, bursaries and artists' project grants (line 13010)
Business income (use 0 if the amount is negative) (line 13500)
Professional income (use 0 if the amount is negative) (line 13700)
Commission income (use 0 if the amount is negative) (line 13900)
Farming income (use 0 if the amount is negative) (line 14100)
Fishing income (use 0 if the amount is negative) (line 14300)
working-income.text1: To calculate your working income, add up all the following lines from your {{year}} tax return:
working-income.description: This is income you made from your employment or self-employment.

partner-working-income.text1: To calculate your partner's working income, add up all the following lines from their {{year}} tax return:
partner-working-income.description: This is income your partner made from their employment or self-employment.

content.completion-time: It will take about 5 to 10 minutes to complete.
content.description: Use this estimator to find out how much money you could get from the Canada Disability Benefit. This is not the application for the benefit.

eligibility.intro: To receive the Canada Disability Benefit, you must meet specific eligibility criteria. <cdbRequirementsLink>Consult the benefit eligibility requirements</cdbRequirementsLink>.

estimator-steps.intro: If you meet the eligibility criteria, use the benefits estimator to find out how much you may receive. The estimator will ask you questions about your:

content.result-disclaimer: This tool provides an estimate only. It doesn't guarantee that you'll be eligible or that you'll receive the amount estimated.

results.contact: For a more accurate assessment of your estimated benefits amount, please <cdbContactLink>contact us</cdbContactLink>.
results.description: This estimator provides estimated benefit amounts for payments made between {{paymentPeriodStart}} and {{paymentPeriodEnd}}. Future benefit amounts may change.

marital-status.form-instructions: All fields are required unless marked as optional

common-law.text: you're living in a conjugal relationship with someone that you are not married to. At least one of the following situations must apply to this person. They:
common-law.item1: have been living with you for at least 12 continuous months. This includes any period you were separated for less than 90 days because of a breakdown in your relationship
common-law.item2: are the parent of your child by birth or adoption
common-law.item3: have custody and control of your child (or had custody and control immediately before your child turned 19 years old) and your child is wholly dependent on that person for support

divorced.text: you were married and are now legally divorced.

separated.text: you've been living apart from your spouse or common-law partner because of a breakdown in the relationship for a period of at least 90 days and you have not reconciled.
separated.p1: Once you've been separated for 90 days, the effective day of your separation is the date you started living apart. If there is no breakdown in your relationship but you are living apart for reasons such as work, studies, or health problems, you would be considered to have a spouse or common-law partner.
separated.p2: Note: You are also generally not considered separated if your spouse or common-law partner is incarcerated or doesn't live in Canada, as long as there is no breakdown in your relationship.

single.text: you're single and none of the statuses below apply to you.

widowed.text: your spouse or common-law partner is deceased.

next-steps.apply-cdb: Apply for the Canada Disability Benefit
next-steps.learn-more: Learn more about the Canada Disability Benefit

married-common-law.cdb-partner-result: If both you and your partner are receiving the Canada Disability Benefit, you could receive a monthly amount of {{result}}.
married-common-law.intro: The monthly benefit amount you could receive depends on whether your partner is receiving the Canada Disability Benefit.
married-common-law.non-cdb-partner-result: If your partner is not receiving the Canada Disability Benefit, you could receive a monthly amount of {{result}}.

your-estimate.note: Please note that you may be able to receive retroactive payments for past months that you were elligible, but not for months before June 2025.

single.intro: You could be eligible to receive:
single.result: A monthly amount of {{result}} from the Canada Disability Benefit.

results.disclaimer-alert: This estimate is based on the information you provided and assumes that you meet the eligibility criteria for the Canada Disability Benefit.
